citations.title: Pages: typically 9 pages main text; references unlimited; appendix in supplementary; use official LaTeX style (confirm on CFP)
Anonymization: double-blind; no self-identifying links during review
Reproducibility: NeurIPS Paper Checklist required
Pages: typically 9 pages main text; references unlimited; official LaTeX style —  and example paper https://media.icml.cc/Conferences/ICML2025/Styles/example_paper.pdf
Pages: typically 9 pages main text; references unlimited; official LaTeX style — https://icml.cc/Conferences/2025/AuthorInstructions and example paper
Pages: typically ~9 pages main text; references unlimited; appendices go in same PDF; OpenReview submission
Anonymization: double-blind on OpenReview
Pages: 8 pages main text; references unlimited; separate supplementary
Anonymization: double-blind; no identifying links during review
Pages: long = 8 pages, short = 4 pages; references unlimited; appendices after references
Anonymization: double-blind (ARR policy)
Reproducibility: Responsible NLP Research Checklist is required as an appendix
Pages: usually long = 8, short = 4; references unlimited
Anonymization: double-blind
Pages: different from CVPR (check official policies); usually separate supplementary
Pages: strict page limits specified in Author Kit; separate supplementary policy
Anonymization: double-blind — see anonymous formatting notes
Reproducibility: AAAI-25 reproducibility checklist
Code/data: encouraged; check ethics and reproducibility requirements
Pages: main track page limits defined in CFP; references unlimited; supplementary allowed
Code/data: encouraged; follow data-use/ethics guidance
Pages: research track page limits specified in CFP
Reproducibility/artifacts: ACM Artifact Badging program offered (optional but valuable) —  and ACM policy https://www.acm.org/publications/policies/artifact-review-and-badging-current
Reproducibility/artifacts: ACM Artifact Badging program offered (optional but valuable) — https://kdd2025.kdd.org/call-for-artifact-badging/ and ACM policy
Pages: research track rules in CFP
Pages: no hard limit but concise papers expected
Pages: no strict page limits; single-blind
Reproducibility: strong code/data policy; MLOSS culture

judges.raw: {"score": 0.8, "rationale": "The response provides a comprehensive mapping of venue-specific expectations and an adapted plan with clear next steps. The three concrete experiments are well-defined with hypotheses, variables, metrics, and expected outcomes. The timeline is also actionable. It also doesn't provide specific commands for artifact packaging, though it details what should be included.", "confidence": "high"}
judges.rationale: The response provides a comprehensive mapping of venue-specific expectations and an adapted plan with clear next steps. It includes specific recommendations for manuscript structure, anonymization, reproducibility, and code/data release. The three concrete experiments are well-defined with hypotheses, variables, metrics, and expected outcomes. The timeline is also actionable. The minor gap is that while it suggests completing checklists early, it doesn't provide direct commands or links to *how* to complete them beyond linking to the checklists themselves. It also doesn't provide specific commands for artifact packaging, though it details what should be included.

The response provides concrete executable steps with specific commands, parameters, and expected outcomes. It includes detailed venue-specific formatting requirements, explicit instructions for anonymization (e.g., 'remove identifying metadata (PDF properties, Git history, model cards)'), reproducibility checklists, code/data release procedures (e.g., 'provide a fully anonymized, self-contained artifact (zip with README)'), and a submission timeline with falsifiable pre-submission experiments (e.g., 'Cross-seed stability test' with 5 random seeds, paired bootstrap test, and expected outcome of significance at α=0.05). The guidance is highly actionable with minimal gaps.

judges.raw: {"score":1.0,"rationale":"The response delivers concrete executable steps across venue mapping and plan adaptation, including specific page limits, anonymization procedures (e.g., metadata scrubbing, anonymized zip with README), reproducibility requirements (e.g., checklists, dataset licenses, scripts, hardware details), code/data release protocols (e.g., self-contained zip during review, public repo with DOI post-acceptance), a timed submission checklist (e.g., T-6 weeks: lock scope and run experiments with 3 seeds), and three detailed pre-submission experiments with hypotheses, variables, metrics (e.g., mean ± std, Spearman ρ ≥ 0.8), and expected outcomes, fully aligning with rubric criteria for 1.0 without significant gaps.","confidence":"high"}
